title: SB 127
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature acknowledges that many areas in California are disproportionately affected by drought due to heavy reliance on overdrafted or contaminated groundwater basins. There are state grant and loan programs to help communities with water needs, but individual homeowners with groundwater wells lack similar assistance for vital water improvements. The program created by this act aims to provide low-interest loans, grants, or both to individual homeowners for safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment. Actions may include digging deeper wells, improving existing wells, addressing water contaminants, or connecting to a local water system. Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code establishes a Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program to provide low-interest loans and grants to local agencies for various purposes such as extending service lines, connecting to water systems, and closing abandoned septic tanks and water wells for health and safety reasons. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Program under Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code covers costs for closing abandoned septic tanks and water wells, deepening or improving groundwater wells, and installing water treatment systems if needed to meet drinking standards. The board has the authority to adopt regulations necessary for program implementation. The Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund is established in the State Treasury for expenditure by the board in accordance with Chapter 6.6 of the Water Code. Eligible loan applicants must meet specific criteria. An eligible applicant for a loan from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders, and demonstrate an ability to repay the loan. To qualify for a loan from the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund, applicants must have a household income below the statewide median, own the residence, and show the ability to repay the loan. The loan must be secured by a mortgage on the residence, repaid within 20 years at a 1 percent interest rate, and maintain homeowner's insurance on the property. The board may contract with a private financial institution to provide loans under certain criteria. Eligible applicants must have a household income below 60% of the statewide median, own the residence, and be unable to obtain financial assistance from private lenders. SEC. 3. Ten million dollars ($10,000,000) is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund. SEC. 4. A grant recipient must repay the full amount if they sell the residence within five years of signing the agreement or return any unused funds to the board. Ten million dollars is transferred from the General Fund to the Water and Wastewater Loan and Grant Fund to provide eligible households with access to safer, cleaner, and more reliable drinking water and wastewater treatment during California's prolonged drought. This act is an urgency statute necessary for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety. Section 21168.6.7 of the Public Resources Code defines a "water project" as one funded by bonds from the Water Quality, Supply and Infrastructure Improvement Act of 2014. The procedures outlined in subdivision (c) apply to legal actions challenging the certification of environmental impact reports or approvals for water projects. The Judicial Council must establish procedures for resolving legal actions challenging the certification of environmental impact reports for water projects within 270 days. Environmental impact reports for water projects must include a notice in at least 12-point type. The final environmental impact report for a water project must include a notice in not less than 12-point type stating that certain comments filed after the public comment period may not be considered. Judicial actions challenging the certification of the EIR or project approval are subject to specific procedures outlined in the Public Resources Code. The draft and final environmental impact reports must include the full text of specific sections. The lead agency must conduct an informational workshop and hold a public hearing during the public comment period. A transcript of the hearing will be included in the final report. Following the public comment period, a commenter on the draft environmental impact report can request nonbinding mediation within five days. The mediation must involve the lead agency, applicant, and all relevant commenters, and must be completed within 35 days. The request for mediation should specify the areas of dispute to be mediated. The lead agency selects mediators with expertise in land use and environmental law or science for mediation requested by commenters on areas of dispute. The applicant covers the mediation costs, and sessions are held for each disputed area. (D)A mediation session shall be conducted on each area of dispute with the parties requesting mediation. The lead agency must adopt agreed-upon measures as a condition of approval, and comments submitted after the public comment period will not be considered unless they address specific criteria. The lead agency does not have to consider comments submitted after the public comment period, unless they address new issues raised in the response to comments, new information released by the public agency, or changes made to the project after the comment period. The lead agency must consider changes made to the project after the public comment period, proposed conditions for approval, new information not known during the comment period, and file the required notice within five days of the last project approval. The lead agency must file the required notice within five days of the last project approval and prepare the record of proceedings, with costs covered by the applicant. The lead agency must make the draft environmental impact report and related documents available to the public in an electronic format within three business days of its release. Any additional documents related to the report must be accessible within five business days of their preparation or receipt by the lead agency. The lead agency is required to make the draft environmental impact report and related documents available in an electronic format within three business days of release. Copyright protected documents not prepared specifically for the project do not need to be electronically accessible, but an index of these documents must be available electronically by the release of the draft report or within five business days if received later. The index should specify where hardcopies of the copyrighted materials can be reviewed by the public. The lead agency must convert non-electronic comments into electronic format within seven days and make them available to the public. Comments not considered by the lead agency do not need to be included in the record. Within five days of filing the required notice, the lead agency must certify the record of proceedings and provide an electronic copy to a party upon request. A reasonable fee may be charged for the copy. Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. (8) Within 10 days of receiving a complaint or petition, the lead agency must lodge a copy of the certified record with the superior court. (9) Any disputes over the record's content will be resolved by the superior court, with parties needing to file a motion to augment the record if necessary. (10) The contents of the record must comply with Section 21167.6. The court shall not stay construction of a water project unless there is an imminent threat to public health and safety. The court may stay construction of a water project if it poses a threat to public health and safety or if it impacts important Native American artifacts, historical, archaeological, or ecological values. The court may enjoin specific activities of a water project that pose a threat to public health, safety, or important cultural and ecological values. Any challenge to a project approval decision must follow Chapter 6 requirements. No reimbursement is required for this act as local agencies or school districts can levy charges to cover mandated services.
